text: . explores this topic in depth in part two of our series on Lightning Network vulnerabilities:
name: CoinDesk

text:
As Lightning grows and builders try to strike a balance between user-friendliness and security, addressing these attacks will require careful deliberation.
 
And maybe a bit of pressure from adversaries,  thinks, could help set security priorities for development.
name: CoinDesk

text:
Some of these attack vectors will be less vulnerable thanks to Lightning's new “anchor channels," which will allow users to update fees on the go when closing channels.
 
This update, though, has exposed a new vulnerability, a reminder that innovation can create complications.
name: CoinDesk

text:
Since they are so difficult to pull off, they haven't been a priority.
 
“It almost feels like you’re going to prepare Earth for a meteor that will destroy life but it hasn’t happened! If there’s no actual attack then it’s hard to keep attention on these problems." 
-
name: CoinDesk

text: For most hackers, these exploits are either too difficult to pull off or don't provide enough loot to justify the effort. And those with the expertise - the developers building on Lightning - are more focused on collaboration than subterfuge.
name: CoinDesk

text:
The Lightning Network has attack vectors that have never been exploited.
 
Why have the vulnerabilities been left untouched? 
 
A thread on why Lightning has never weathered an attack, and what can be done about the existing attack vectors. 🧵👇

text: How concerned are you about Lightning vulnerabilities?
name: CoinDesk

text:
Why have none of these vulnerabilities ever been exploited in the wild?
 
That’s something we’ll answer in part two, as well as discuss potential fixes and why a little adversarial pressure might be good to harden the network's defense. ⌛️
name: CoinDesk

text: Some of these vulnerabilities are more feasible and costly than others.  explains them in the first article of a two-part series on existing vulnerabilities in Bitcoin’s Lightning network:
name: CoinDesk

text:
4. Another attack that requires incomplete transaction data: the pinning attack. 

To exploit this vulnerability, a sophisticated attacker could block a channel’s closing transaction by broadcasting conflicting transactions to nodes that aren’t connected with each other.
name: CoinDesk

text:
3. The time-dilation attack, the most complex and serious of the bunch, requires a “sybil attack” on a victim’s Lightning node.

With the node’s connections “eclipsed,” the attacker can feed it transaction data at a slower rate in hopes of stealing funds from closing LN channels.
name: CoinDesk

text: 2. For a “flood and loot” attack, an attacker would spam routed payments through a victim’s node and force close each channel together. If any of the closing transactions failed when broadcasted on-chain, the attacker could claim them by re-sending the same BTC with a higher fee.
name: CoinDesk

text:
1. “Griefing” attacks have been possible since Lightning's launch and involve freezing the funds in a payment channel by maxing out its HTLC limit.
 
Relative to other Lightning vulnerabilities, griefing isn’t as threatening as attackers can only freeze funds, not steal them.
name: CoinDesk

text:
Developers have discovered a number of vulnerabilities in Bitcoin’s Lightning Network over the years. Some are more serious than others, most are very tricky to pull off and none have been exploited.
 
Here's how these attack vectors work 🧵👇
